<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 330, 312]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 278, 904, 333]]<|/det|>
0625/61October/November 20181 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 390, 386, 406]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 768, 546]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 758, 586]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 725, 91]]<|/det|>
A student is determining the spring constant \(k\) of a spring by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 467, 121]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2 shows how the apparatus is used.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 136, 202, 151]]<|/det|>
# Method 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 167, 146, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 713, 184]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, measure the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the spring, in mm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 491, 470, 508]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[572, 917, 755, 937]]<|/det|>
<form>l = ................................... 53 .................... mm

<label>(d)</label>

Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each centimetre of the wire. Use the equation \(R = \frac{Gk}{I}\), where \(k = 1.0 \text{V/cm}\) and where \(I\) is the current recorded in (a).

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 806, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is determining the refractive index \(n\) of the material of a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 593, 121]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows the outline \(\mathbf{ABCD}\) of the transparent block.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 134, 845, 780]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 823, 532, 840]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 183, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 73, 297, 90]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 103, 573, 121]]<|/det|>
• draw a normal **NL** at the centre of side **AB**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 135, 767, 152]]<|/det|>
• continue the normal so that it passes through side **CD** of the block

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 166, 545, 183]]<|/det|>
• label the point **F** where **NL** crosses **AB**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 197, 552, 214]]<|/det|>
• label the point **G** where **NL** crosses **CD**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 197, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 228, 180, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 228, 836, 245]]<|/det|>
Draw a line **EF** at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the left of the normal and above side **AB**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 228, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 259, 180, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 259, 918, 291]]<|/det|>
Mark the positions of two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line **EF** placed at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-tracing experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 305, 148, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 918, 338]]<|/det|>
The student observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side **CD** of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 351, 918, 384]]<|/det|>
He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between his eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) , \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 397, 573, 415]]<|/det|>
The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are marked on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 429, 181, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 429, 918, 462]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . Continue the line until it meets the normal **NL**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 476, 766, 492]]<|/det|>
• Label the point **H** where the line meets side **CD**. Draw the line **FH**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 492, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 180, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 588, 540]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(a\) of the line **GH**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 553, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<form>a = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 584, 180, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 584, 585, 600]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(b\) of the line **FH**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 615, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
<form>b = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 645, 180, 663]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 644, 690, 670]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 707, 920, 724]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 161, 670, 187]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[566, 262, 920, 279]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the relationship between the power produced by an electrical heater and the time taken to heat a beaker of water. The power of the heater is given by the equation \(P = VI\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the heater and \(I\) is the current in the heater.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 918, 167]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the relationship between the power produced by an electrical heater and the time taken to heat a beaker of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 181, 420, 197]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 214, 237, 228]]<|/det|>
ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 230, 237, 243]]<|/det|>
voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 245, 400, 259]]<|/det|>
0–12 V variable power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 260, 288, 274]]<|/det|>
250 cm³ beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 276, 215, 288]]<|/det|>
heater

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 291, 266, 304]]<|/det|>
thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 307, 250, 320]]<|/det|>
stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 336, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
The student can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 383, 218, 397]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 413, 775, 429]]<|/det|>
· complete the diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show the circuit that you would use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 655, 460]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 475, 568, 491]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 505, 918, 537]]<|/det|>
· draw a table with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 552, 704, 567]]<|/det|>
· explain how you would use your results to reach a conclusion.
